answers.answer: You know,LOL. first of all, I have no idea what spleen pain would be. BUT, if it is indeed my spleen, it's not like excruciating bad pain that I have to stay in bed. I would call it more of a "soreness" pain from my sternum, to upper left rib cage, to my lower left side.  and then it wraps around to my upper left back like someone is "knifing" me..you know?  Also, if I press my sternum, I can here it 'click'. lol. But now my ribs on my right and left are tad sore. a little, not SO much.  but here's a bright spot. When I went to the STD clinic last week (at the 4 week mark) to get tested, the doc said that's no sign of an STD and said to talk to my general practitioner. I have been eating a lot since all this began and as a result have gained weight, so maybe my digestive system is reacting to the extra stress I've been puttin on it, not to mention my mental anxiety.And all this time I was thinking that my jaw has been tight and after feeling my lymph nodes in my neck that they are swollen, she (the STD doc) felt them and my groin nodes and said nothing swollen.  I asked her, I have been trying to feel them and they feel swollen. She said to stop that cuz that will irritate your nodes.  In my mind I said (woops! guess I was bein over anxious and paranoid!).but, all in all, I think I'm okay.I just got tested at 4 weeks, and will know by 22nd Nov, what the result is.  I'm hoping negative, but logically speaking, it should be negative.I'll keep u updated. You do the same.-WorriedUS

I don't have to stay in bed but all the pain put together (The left side, underarm, right shoulder, calf muscles cramps and headaches) makes me want to!I really need to get my 12 weeks test-Just so scared! :-(

Well, I wanna say if everything like that is aching, then it would probably be stress.  But you've already had negative tests, haven't you? 12 weeks should be the icing on the cake.I'm still waiting for my first test results at 4 weeks! lol-WorriedUS

Look, hardly anyone really uses condoms for oral (in my whole life, I've only met ONE person, ONE time who did, and that's only because they were afraid of getting HSV1 from me). You did not do anything unusual or particularly risky.So are you this worried about getting struck by lightning? Same 1 in 10,000 chance...
Risk even as high as 1 to 1000 sounds low but as the good Dr once said would you play Russian roulette with a gun with 100 chambers. I guess that

Worried hope everything goes well. I did a 27 day and was negative, which is cutting it maybe a might early, but I'm doing a 6 week on the 30th. After that I'll do a 13 week and then put it out of my mind. Hope yours goes well.

I had a test after I came out of a relationship and found out my partner had been with other women. That was negative and was taken just over 2 weeks after I had performed oral sex on another man-I didn't realise HIV can be contracted via oral until I was awaiting results from the test. It was far too soon to be able to tell from that test!
Put it like that and it sounds a lot lower! ha
I still think that lightning strike probability is a dubious number. <tongue-in-cheek here>.

I was interested in this too, so I did some reading. Estimates vary widely, and much depends on where you are (Florida vs. Alaska, outside golfing vs. doing laundry in the basement) but generally it's said you have a 1 in 10,000 chance of being struck by lightning in your lifetime. Annually, it's about a 1 in 290,000 chance.Here's a more alarming statistic: you have a 1 in 7 chance of developing breast cancer in your lifetime, and a 1 in 3 chance of developing diabetes. But I bet most of the posters think nothing of eating a Big Mac and extra-large fries, smoking cigarettes, not exercising... What I'm wondering is, where are the boards for people afraid of diabetes? Cancer? Heart disease? All of those things are MUCH, MUCH more likely to kill you, even when you're young. What is it about HIV that's so frightening for people?So I have a theory. It involves childhood messages about sex, religion (ironically enough, the ones who are most freaked out seem to reference their enormous faith and thanks to god for "pulling them through"), guilt (over sex in general, "risky" partners, discomfort with sexual orientation, relationship status, whatever), and health anxiety in general. I'd love to know how many times people see their doctor per year. Oh, and I definitely suspect that these wild, unreasonable fears are a defense mechanism; they help keep folks from focusing on the very real and REALLY frightening issues in their daily lives.What do you guys think? Am I on track? What do you think drives you to worry so much about HIV and STDs in general? What do you think could help you relax a bit?

Regardless of personal views, let's not 'attack' anyone on any of these threads.  we can state our opinions, and not come down on anyone from our moral 'high' grounds. No one person on here has their own personal soap box to stand on in these threads.  monkeyflower has her own opinions; she can express them.  So does dumbo.  So do I.  Emotions cannot be displayed over the net and she might be insinuating something different, all the while being assertive. Let's give her and all others the benefit of the doubt. Not even the Good Doctor Handsfield makes judgments on our sexual outlets --prostitutes, escorts, one-night-stands, Carnival in Rio Brazil (I saw a couple of posts on that).  He merely says how we can be safe.  That's it. Point blank.Let's state our opinion, and not say "typical and expected" when people don't KNOW each other on these forums.My thoughts.-WorriedUS

I agree monkeyflower, totally but I have something to add..since there is a big flip side to this rather NEW disease.1)True, that in this country diabetes, heart disease and the like kill way more people than HIV.  (500,000+ for Heart Disease ailments, 70,000+ for diabetes ailments and ONLY 15,000+ for HIV and AIDS-related complications).  I got the figures from wrongdiagnosis.com and cdc.gov. (Verify anyone??)2) ALSO true, that given the chronic and irreversible nature of HIV and its AIDS-related complications, most people WILL understandably live longer, and have greater chances of living than say complications from diabetes or heart disease.  It was once a death sentence, but now more a chronic disease, like you said in a post I read earlier. Most people can now expect to live an average of 24 years, according to Dr. Bruce Schackman, an assistant professor of public health at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University in New York. And that is just an average. But I would surmise it is probably much longer for many more newly infected people I think because of all the new pipelines of HIV medications from the pharm companies, new gene therapy for CD4 cells, and the availability of medication to those in a Western country. See link below.(http://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/12/us/12hiv.html?ex=1164171600&en=5e4849829dd56222&ei=5040&partner=MOREOVERFEATURES3) But, and here is a BIG 'but', even though less people die from this disease than most other common American incurable epidemics, most people are going to have to undertake much more drastic (arbirtrary word here cuz I'm aware that diabetes, for e.g., does involve drastic nutritional and lifestyle changes but perhaps certain cancers do not) lifestyle changing attitudes and decisions based on their infections, i.e., marriage, relationsihps, health, and financials. Case in point--it costs on average more than $600,000 in a lifetime in health care costs for an HIV infected patient (same story, link above). Not to mention the social stigma STILL attached to having something like HIV as opposed to diabetes or a heart disease complication such as a heart attack. For example, the thought that it is a disease mostly acquired through promiscuity, it still possibly being ill-conceived as an overly contagious (as opposed to other higher risk but non-contagious epidemics like diabetes, cancer, heart disease, etc.), or perhaps in still some conservative circles, it being thought of as a 'gay' disease so to speak ---just generalizing here, not everyone believes it is a gay disease as such, I admit, however, it still has that "raised" eyebrow ponderance upon the faces of some when the mere mention AIDS or HIV is uttered, as if to say it is not appropriate dinner talk.Until HIV is understood more, more sex education is disseminated, more breakthrough research is done to counter the epidemic, more effective drugs become available,  and perhaps most important, society in general has a much more benign attitude towards HIV via education, it will be a mortifier, at least mentally and thus continue to drive anxiety-driven posters like myself and others on this message board website to ask such questions about whether HIV transmission really deserves merit in low risk sexual encounters or even in a monogamous setting.Silver lining?  From my simpleminded opinion, I can say, it seems that it is rather EXTREMELY difficult to get infected. I mean, just look at the probability of infection at 1/2000 for heterosexual encounters and 6/10,000 for insertive homosexual encounters! how about 1/10,000 for receptive fellatio!!(http://ww2.aegis.org/pubs/mmwr/2005/r402a1t1.gif).  It takes a good amount of the virus to infect you i.e., from an epidemiologically standpoint. Doc H has said that different viral levels to infect a person will still result in a person having HIV and eventually full blow AIDS, if the transmission route is a successful one to the bloodstream. However, it seems that it takes an almost inordinate amount, read A LOT, of the virus for a greater probability of infection due to an abundance of factors, i.e., fragility of the virus to live outside of the body for more than a few seconds.Bottomline, even though it's impossible to get cured, it's almost virtually difficult to get infected from one or even several sexual encounters.  And if you played it safe, you played it safe.  But lack of understanding and education about a relatively new disease, among other things, is ample reason for the births of a lot Worry Worts, and understandably so!just my thoughts.-WorriedUS

Well....I have done some (a lot of) research myself today...Although some sites will say 'some may have an enlarged spleen' relating to HIV it would seem if you actually search spleen problems on google-NONE of the results came back with HIV-and we all know how easy it is to search a symptom and be bombarded with HIV HIV HIV HIV HIV results-Which is what got us all worrying in the first place...It would seem a more likely explanation would be due to liver problems OR it not actually being the spleen that is causing pain but the liver its self putting pressure on it. Thats how I read it anyway...And considering I drink a lot-and binge drink A LOT on the weekends-I think this would be a much more likely explanation! And 100 times more common than HIV!

monkeyflower said " (ironically enough, the ones who are most freaked out seem to reference their enormous faith and thanks to god for "pulling them through")"Such hypocrisy.  You want people to be "tolerant" of gays and alternative lifestyles, yet you criticize those who seek spiritual comfort?!.  Are you not tolerant of this?  Where is your live and let live spirit you seem to portray in your pro alternative lifestyle posts? .  Typical and expected.The truth because people are so scared to state the obvious, people are freaked about HIV because, unless someone is born with it (because of the following activities) it is primarily a gay disease, and IV/needle sharing disease.  As a result, there is an obvious stigma attached to HIV.
To be honest I don't see 1 in 10,000 as being very low!

WorriedUS: Dumbo and I had a little disagreement over on one of the other boards, so we know quite well where the other stands.Dumbo: Damn right I'm intolerant... of intolerance. See, I don't care what you or anyone else does (whether you go to church, etc.), until it impacts those of us who don't agree with you. The religious right, on the other hand, can't rest until everyone's going to Christian churches, gay marriage is banned, and the whole world lives the way THEY think everyone should live.

"The religious right, on the other hand, can't rest until everyone's going to Christian churches, gay marriage is banned, and the whole world lives the way THEY think everyone should live."You just don't see your hypocrisy, do you?

That post was completely contradictory.  You are intolerant of the intolerant unless you can't tolerate what someone else does then you become intolerant.... lol.  Hypocrisy at its finest.I have said repeatedly, live and let live..just do not try to impose your thoughts/beliefs/morals/personal opinion etc on me and it's all good.The gay/alternative lifestyle will NEVER EVER be tolerated, in my lifetime, or yours or future generations.  It's that simple.  No matter how hard it is pushed for, it will never be 100% accepted by everyone.  Neither will fat people, drugs users, steroid users, black/minorities, and very sad to say, even the handicapped.  There are ~6billion people on the planet, and not everyone will see eye to eye nor can they be forced to do so.Your holier than thou posts will not change my views anyway.  So why waste your time?

This is my last post to you. I'm just going to say again that I don't care what anyone else does, as long as it doesn't impact my life and my rights as a human being. So go to church, do what you want with your life. Have sex with men or women. I don't care. I'm not stopping you, and I don't want to stop you.But you DO want to stop people from living their lives and doing what they feel. You DO discriminate against people for what they believe/feel/look like. And that's the problem. You want to impose your beliefs on everyone else. I just don't want you or anyone else to hurt others.

monkeyflower said "But you DO want to stop people from living their lives and doing what they feel. You DO discriminate against people for what they believe/feel/look like. And that's the problem. You want to impose your beliefs on everyone else."Ya, right. That's what I've been saying all along....lol...sheesh.  Yet if you read a few posts above I say (yet again) live and let live.Again, you do not get it.  You do not, and refuse to see, your own hypocrisy.

question: Hey WorriedUS how is yours feeling?I am still getting this constant and sometimes quite unbearable spleen pain!
title: Spleen pain
